editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: Invi≈øible IOHN made Vi≈øible: OR A grand Pimp of Tyranny portrayed, &c.
div.p: THe old Roman Laelius, mentioned in Lucan's Phar≈øalio, was not more mercenariou≈øly devoted to ≈øerve the will and lu≈øt of Cae≈øar, than late experience hath proved the plyablene≈ø≈øe of ≈øome Engli≈øh Para≈øites, to gratifie the greate≈øt of Tyrants in the ba≈øe≈øt and beggerlye≈øt Drudgeries. No Dog can be more ready to run on a Bul or Bear at a ≈øtake, than the≈øe Mini≈øters of mi≈øchief, and In≈øtruments of cruelty, have been fierce to fall on the mo≈øt innocent, upon the lea≈øt beek or nod of the Tyrant: They have been ≈øo far (as would have become Engli≈øh men and Chri≈øtians) from refu≈øing obedience to ≈øuch Commands as carried not with them the Authority of Law and Ju≈øtice, as that they have been ready (even to the ruining of mens per≈øons & e≈øtates) to execute ≈øuch Orders as have been diametrically oppo≈øite to both: yea, BY VIRTVE ONLY of their very power and ≈øtations, have they ≈øo highly invaded the proprieties of tho≈øe whom their, or their Ma≈øters malice hath been pro≈øecuting, as if they had been within no bounds of Law, Rea≈øon or Religion, or that there was no account to be given either in this ot another world.

But to proceed to that per≈øon again≈øt whom the Barteries of Ju≈øtice by this piece of Paper are more particularly (yet publickly and not per≈øonally) levell'd: I ≈øhall de≈øire tho≈øe who are now handing the Helm of publick Tran≈øactions, and promi≈øe ≈øo to ≈øteer the cour≈øe of this Commonwealth, that we may arrive at ≈øome ≈øuch hopeful Harbour, wherein w ‚Ä¢ may in futu ‚Ä¢ o, be ≈øheltered from tho≈øe blu≈øtering Storms which had almo≈øt ≈øhattered us in p ‚Ä¢ eces, to con≈øider how far the pre≈øent Jaylor of the Tower, Colonel Iohn Bark≈øtead, alias Baxter, (whom the decea≈øed Tyrant had ≈øo trayn'd up in Tyranny, that he was become ≈øufficiently tractable to Ape him, and act his part in any Trea≈øon and Oppre≈ø≈øion) hath in≈øolently run him≈øelf into guilt beyond all others who either may de≈øerve, or upon ≈øome pardonable grounds de≈øire Indempnity, and con≈øequently
rendered him≈øelf uncapable of being continued in ≈øo con≈øiderable a tru≈øt as the Tower, which he hath made ≈øo obnoxious to igminy and contempt, that per≈øons of honour and credit will be very ≈øhy of ≈øucceeding him in ≈øuch a ≈øcornful ≈øcar. Now n t knowing how confident he may yet continue under an invi≈øibleTho≈øe who are acquainted with the Story of the Stone lent him by an Italian to make him invi≈øible, wil under≈øtand my meaning conceit, I judged it incumbent upon me to cheque him at the ≈øtairs head, before he run down with the Tower, as once he did with a di≈øh of meat, when he was by a merry company cajowled in ≈øuch a frollick, as then rendred him as great a fool as ≈øince he hath made him≈øelf a knave: And therefore more ≈øoberly than po≈ø≈øibly ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages may ≈øignifie me, I have ≈øent forth this en≈øuing Charge again≈øt him: the truth of which, and much more, will be ≈øeconded by many, if opportunity be but offered thereunto.

Fir≈øt, He the ≈øaid Bark≈øtead, Lieutenant of the Tower, contrary to the Laws of this Nation, and the tru≈øt repo≈øed in him, for abetting the boundle≈øs ambition of a Tyrant, and the oppre≈ø≈øing and per≈øecuting of all who would not ≈øubject them≈øelves to ≈ølavery,Major General Overtons Ca≈ø√©, with divers others. hath been a con≈øtant & punctual Ob≈øerver of all commands, Orders and Directions publick and private, which came from the late Tyrant, or his grand Pimp Thu ‚Ä¢ loc; and in impri≈øoning of mens Per≈øons, bani≈øhing them beyond the Seas, torturing them by ≈øtrict re≈øtraints in the Tower, keeping them up clo≈øe from the comfort of Wives, Relations or Friends,As in Armigers Ca≈øe, who≈øe mouth they ≈øay he hath stopped by Compo≈øition. denying them the benefit of Law by Habeas Corpus, when it ≈øtood not with the Tyrants liking, breaking open of Hou≈øes, illegal ≈øearchings, Exactions and Impo≈øitions; hath been the mo≈øt indefatigable Drudge in this Nation to the late Tyrant: and for the more effectual managing of the≈øe his Ma≈øters affairs, be con≈øtantly employed ≈øome Souldiers and Officers, as Emi≈ø≈øaries and Trappanners abroad, who under the notion of di≈øcovering Delinquents, and di≈ø≈øatisfied per≈øons, have committed mo≈øt notorious Villanies, in forcing ≈øeveral peaceable per≈øons not within his Cognizance, to come and give the ≈øaid Bark≈øtead bond, meerly for the Fee ≈øake, and in taking money from others not to di≈øcover their delinquency: divers of whom, though they could have put in ≈øufficient Pleas for them≈øelvs, ≈øubmitted to any thing, rather than to come within the Tower, which this Bark≈øtead had made ≈øuch a Bug-Bear, that it frighted many from it: yea, his very Clerk for≈øooth had his Agents al≈øo, to make ≈øuch di≈øcoveries as might augment his gain.

2. He the ≈øaid Bark≈øtead, contrary to Law, and the Tru≈øt repro≈øed in him, hath, during the time of his Government in the Tower, made ≈øuch private Laws and Orders as have carried in them no other weight,A Lady was forced to pay 20 s. for her ≈øelf and Servants; and yet 'tis ≈øaid, She ≈øtaid not above the time allowed by his order. &
been of no other u≈øe and tendency than to en≈ønare and trapan tho≈øe who came to vi≈øit per≈øecuted and oppre≈ø≈øed Pri≈øoners into forfeitures of monies;I have heard, and believe it is true, that 15 s. was forced from two Kin≈øwomen and a Son of Major General Overtons, ≈øor but accidentally meeting of him as he was walking within the Tower, they having been to ≈øee the Armory. which hath been from time to time exacted from them by very coar≈øe and inhumane u≈øage: and upon refu≈øal, many, both men and women, have been ca≈øt into Guards for divers hours; yea, ≈øome women who have had ≈øucking children, could not obtain their Liberty, divers having been continued nights and dayes during his plea≈øure: with which monies ≈øo extorted, the Officers of the Guards have oft made them≈øelves drunk, and the ≈øaid Bark≈øtead hath ≈øeen it, known it, & pa≈øt it by.

3. The ≈øaid Lieutenant of the Tower, without any publick direction, or legal Authority, as Lieutenant of the Tower, hath ≈øeveral times, by his own Arbitrary power, upon occa≈øion of di≈øcontent with ≈øome Pri≈øoners, impo≈øed a clo≈øe re≈øtraint upon all, till many have been ready to peri≈øh for want of air and exerci≈øe; and being ambitious of homage, hath pragmatically continued this clo≈øe confinement upon them, till they have petitioned him for liberty to walk: and tho≈øe who could not in Con≈øcience thus humour him with Cringes and Cour ‚Ä¢ ≈øhip,Major General Overton, as him≈øelf and others have a≈ø≈øerted, was kept clo≈øe in his Chamber ≈øix Moneths together; that re≈øtraint upon him and the re≈øt being occa≈øioned by divers P ‚Ä¢ i≈øoners dining together, and yet Major General Overton was not out of his Chamber that day: yea, when the ≈øaid Lieutenant was informed that this worthy Gentleman was almo≈øt de≈øtroyed for want of air and exerci≈øe, yet for ≈øix months together he po≈øitively refu≈øed him liberty to walk. he would not allow them the benefit of the air.

4. The ≈øaid Lieutenant of the Tower hath rai≈øed him≈øelf a va≈øt E≈øtate by exacting uncon≈øcionable Fees from Pri≈øoners; yea, from ≈øome who had not bread to put in their mouths. The≈øe Fees he con≈øtantly demanded at their coming in, and would allow them no liberty nor accommodation till they either paid him, or gave ≈øecurity for it; having very uncivilly treated and threatned ≈øome for not coming up to his Demands. Now for the≈øe Fees there is no other colour of Law or Cu≈øtome, than that formerly there was a voluntary gratuity given by Pri≈øoners to the Lieutenant of the Tower for his pains in receiving and paying to them the publick allowance, which in Bark≈øteads time Pri≈øoners have not enjoyed; yet notwith≈øtanding, I believe it may be made appear that one Gentleman after an Order came for his relea≈øe, was continued divers moneths, either becau≈øe he could not, or would not, pay a Fee.

5. That the ≈øaid Lieutenant of the Tower hath ingro≈ø≈øed to him≈øelf (not appertaining to him by vertue of his place ≈øeveral advantages in and about the Tower, by which he rai≈øed a va≈øt ≈øum of money yearly, as upon examination will appear.

6. That the ≈øaid Lieutenant of the Tower, for his own, and Relations Advantage and Accomodation, hath expended (under the notion of nece≈ø≈øary repairs) much of the publick money in fitting and making up Lodgings for Pri≈øoners, from whom there hath been extorted mo≈øt unrea≈øonable rates for the ≈øaid Lodgings: As for in≈øtance: The ≈øaid Lieutenant hath him≈øelf received to his own private u≈øe from Mr. A≈øhburnham 40 s. a week;I have heard that Major General Overton, lodging at one Mr. Cuttingmans the Lieutenant of the Towers brother, and refu≈øing any longer to pay as he had done 30 s. a week for his lodging; the ≈øaid Lieutenant of the Tower threatned in the hearing of a Gentleman of worth, to put the Major General in the Dungeon. from Sir Henry Littleton, 40 s. a week, and from Sir Tho. P yton, forty ≈øhillings a week, or thereabouts; which they in prudence complyed withall, to the end they might enjoy that Freedom and Liberty which others could not have, and they paid dear for; be≈øides great weekly ≈øums which his Kindred received for tho≈øe Lodgings which ought to be free for Pri≈øoners: In≈øomuch that the Tower, formerly a noble and unexpen≈øive Pri≈øon, is by him the ≈øaid Bark≈øtead's ba≈øe practi≈øes and connivances rendred a rooking Pinfold; many being rai≈øed in that place by the ruines of poor Pri≈øoners.

7. The Ca≈øe of Mr. John Partman brought before the late A≈ø≈øembly, who voted his Impri≈øonment illegal and unju≈øt, de≈øerves Con≈øideration, and is of it ≈øelf ≈øingly ≈øufficient to turn ≈øuch a Traytor as this ba≈øe Truck ‚Ä¢ er out of the Tower; who in this ca≈øe fir≈øt plaid the Knave, at la≈øt the Fool.

8. That the ≈øaid Lieutenant of the Tower hath demeaned him≈øelf ≈øo in≈øolently towards Pri≈øoners, & their Friends who came to vi≈øit them,E≈øpecially to that worthy Per≈øon Major General Overton, his Wife, Children and Friends, as I have heard, and I believe is publickly known. and rendred him≈øelf ≈øo ridiculous in both publick and more private gro≈øs practi≈øes, (which I ≈øhall here decline in≈øetting) that he hath cau≈øed much reproach to fall upon Religion, and by that means is become ≈øo ≈øcandalous all the Nation over, that he ≈øtinks in the No≈øtrils of both Good and Bad.

9. And la≈øtly, That it may appear how meer a Time-≈øerving Truckler he the ≈øaid Bark≈øtead is, as plainly and undeniably he was; and how he now clo≈øes in with a Commonwealth from no other principles than the pre≈øervation of his intere≈øt, and to ≈øhelter him≈øelf under the Armies ≈øhield from the La≈øhes of Law, which otherwi≈øe might light heavily upon him; It may be made manife≈øt that he was improving all the intere≈øt he had to ≈øecure the Tower for the late Protector, alias Mr. Richard Cromwel, in oppo≈øition to the Army, till he was frighted forth of that a≈ø≈øay by a Colonel who told him he was undone if he complyed not with the Army, as that Colonel hath confe≈ø≈øed in the audience of forty Per≈øons.
Now if this Charge bear ≈øuch a proportion with truth, as that the ≈øaid Lieutenant of the Tower is guilty of the Sub≈øtance of what is in this Paper alleaged again≈øt him: Then

1. DOth it ≈øtand with the honour and reputation of the Parliament and Army, and the ≈øafety and ≈øecurity of the Tower, to continue him in that command? Or (according to what the Parliament hath lately voted, and the Army have publickly declared to pull the wicked out of their places) to receive him into any other Office or Place of Tru≈øt and Power within the Commonwealth? Or can it be rationally under≈øtood that the Army (under an owning of their late Apo≈øtacy and real repentance for the ≈øame) do or can propo≈øe Indemnity for all, with out any Di≈øtinction either in relation to per≈øons or things?

2. If he, and ≈øuch as he be continued, and tho≈øe who for Con≈øcience ≈øake either ≈øaperated from the late Apo≈øtacy, or were laid a≈øide by the grand Apo≈øtate, are left out; what then doth the late great Noy≈øe and Change naturally and intentionally ≈øignifie, farther than a tran≈ølation of the Apo≈øtatical Cau≈øe and De≈øign (under the Cloak of the Good Old Cau≈øe) out of Oliver Cromwels Family into ≈øome other? Or out of a ≈øingle Per≈øon into ≈øeveral Per≈øons, where Tyranny ≈øtill remains the ≈øame, as ≈øtinking water that may be poured out of one into ≈øeveral ve≈ø≈øels, but remains the ≈øame water, though the ve≈ø≈øels were never ≈øo ≈øweet?

3 Should the Army return no nearer the Good Old Cau≈øe in their repentance for their declen≈øion from it, than to ≈øuch an Oligarchy wherein they may ≈øhrowd and ≈øhelter a private intere≈øt in oppo≈øition to the publick; will they not plainly unveyl the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt Hypocri≈øie in the world, in profe≈ø≈øing them≈øelves ≈øen≈øible of an Apo≈øtacy, and expre≈ø≈øing repentance for it, when at that time they re≈øolved to remain in it? Will they not thereby plainly prove them≈øelves Apo≈øtates indeed, not ≈øuch as were led a≈øide by weakne≈ø≈øes, but ≈øuch as wilfully and wickedly turned out of the way? Oh how will they then ≈øtink as corrupt Carrion in the No≈øtrils of all Nations?

4. If the Parliament and Council of State walk by the Armies Rule in this re≈øpect, and they go hand in hand together, and perpetuate them≈øelves (as I hope neither Parliament nor Army intend) will they not therby in practi≈øe ju≈øtifie that wickedne≈øs in the Apo≈øtacy, which mo≈øt of them condemned in words? And will they not al≈øo according to the Tenour of this Text, Thou art made whole: go thy way, ≈øin no more, le≈øt a wor≈øe thing befall thee be judicially engaged into that which will rather perpetuate their infamy, than their power; ≈øo that the old reproaches ca≈øt upon them, will revive with a new remembrance, and they will really ju≈øtifie tho≈øe who ≈øeem to condemn them≈øelves for interrupting them, and as really condemn them≈øelves in that wherein they now ≈øeem ju≈øtified? Will they not by this means in≈øtead of healing our Breaches, and re≈øtoring of pathes to dwell in, create further and greater di≈ø-unions, and ≈øo
give the common Enemy that opportunity, which will undoubtedly and undeniably e≈øtabli≈øh his Throne in the mid≈øt of us?

5. But if the Parliament and Council of State have more real thoughts for Reformation, (as I hope they have) how comes it then to pa≈ø≈øe that they receive tho≈øe into places and preferment under them, who were actually engaged in the Apo≈øtacy, and reJect, at lea≈øt neglect tho≈øe who have ≈øuffered for Con≈øcience ≈øake, they being equally able with tho≈øe they entertain, and far hone≈øter? Doth not this argue great ingratitude to tho≈øe who have denyed them≈øelves, to vindicate their power? And is it not very unbecoming the profe≈ø≈øions they make, rather to countenance tho≈øe who court them for places, than ≈øuch as in con≈øcience cannot ≈øeek them≈øelves? If Favour or Friend≈øhip mu≈øt carry it from de≈øert, then doth that ≈øpirit ≈øway the Scepter which Rules in Righteou≈øne≈øs?

I ≈øhall not in this place, nor at this pre≈øent, make mention of the Death of Mr. Syndercom, and what he ≈øuffered in the Tower by him; the Story is too well known, and will not ≈øuddenly be forgotten. I ≈øhall only urge that, to add to his former cruelties, the ≈øaid Lieutenant of the Tower did deal mo≈øt barbarou≈øly and unmercifully with that famous, and Reverend Divine Doctor John Hewyt, who being committed to the Tower upon the ≈øugge≈øtions, and the Jealou≈øies of the late decea≈øed Tyrant, he u≈øed all the wayes that po≈ø≈øibly he could contrive to adde unto his Grievances, and would not grant admittance to many Godly and Reverend Divines who took the paines to come and vi≈øit him in the Day of his Di≈øtre≈ø≈øe; nay he would not ≈øuffer the Honourable Lady his mo≈øt dear Wife to have acce≈øs unto him, but only when he plea≈øed: which among≈øt many other almo≈øt inexpre≈ø≈øible ≈øufferings; was the occa≈øion of a great and dangerous ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, which did afflict him to the jeopardy of his life: whereupon petitioning to the Protector then living, ≈øhe could not procure him the liberty of a cleer air, without putting in great ≈øecurity, and a guard upon his per≈øon, who meant neither to fight nor fly away. It were too long in this place to in≈øert the Injuries with which he was tormented a little before his Execution, when he was preparing him≈øelf for a better world, which were ≈øo intolerable, that a Turk would not offer the like ≈øo the mo≈øt de≈øpicable of Chri≈øtians. For your further ≈øatisfaction in this and the particulars thereof, I ≈øhall referre you to the Petition of his Honourable Con≈øort which ≈øhe pre≈øented to the late di≈ø≈øolved Parliament, at the fir≈øt beginning of their Se≈ø≈øions
